Now, regarding the away goal rule: The claim says they had to use this rule because of the tie. The table doesn't specify whether there was an away goal or not. But in football matches that end in a draw after extra time, the away goal rule can apply if both legs are considered. In this case, FC Nantes is from d1 and Olympique Lyonnais from d2. So, I need to see who played at home.

Looking at the "team 1" and "team 2" columns: FC Nantes is team1, so they were likely playing at home in the first leg, which was 0-0. The second leg (4-4) would have been Olympique Lyonnais's home game because they're team2. So, if both teams scored four goals each on aggregate, and since the away goal rule considers goals scored away from home as more valuable, we need to see who had an away goal in the decisive match.

In the 1st round (team1: FC Nantes vs Olympique Lyonnais), it was 0-0 at FC Nantes' home. In the second leg, Olympique Lyonnais scored four goals at their own stadium (as team2). So, FC Nantes scored all four of their goals in the away game against Olympique Lyonnais, while Olympique scored four at home.

Under the away goal rule, if both teams have equal aggregate scores, the team with more away goals wins. Here, FC Nantes scored 4 away goals (in the second leg), and Olympique Lyonnais didn't score any in the first leg. So FC Nantes would win on away goals because they scored four away.

Wait, but the claim says the match required the away goal rule to decide it. Since the aggregate was tied at 4-4, yes, the away goal rule would be applied. Therefore, the claim is correct.
</think>

The claim is TRUE because FC Nantes and Olympique Lyonnais tied on aggregate 4-4 across both rounds. The second leg's score was 4-4, which, when combined with the first leg's 0-0, makes a total of 4-4.
